name: Alchemy
description: A proto-scientific and philosophical discipline combining elements of chemistry, metallurgy, physics, and medicine with esoteric beliefs.

name: Advanced Distillation
description: Refinement of distillation techniques for producing concentrated substances, essential oils, and spirits.

name: Distillation for Alcoholic Spirits
description: Application of advanced distillation to produce concentrated alcoholic beverages like brandy and whiskey.

name: Basic Chemistry
description: Systematic experimentation with substances, distillation, and refinement processes moving beyond pure alchemy.

name: Feudalism
description: Social, economic, and political system based on land tenure, loyalty, and military service between lords and vassals.

name: Manorialism
description: The economic engine of feudalism; a system of self-sufficient agricultural estates (manors) worked by serfs tied to the land.

name: Engineering
description: Practical application of scientific and mathematical principles for design and construction (e.g., castles, cathedrals).

name: Gothic Architecture
description: Architectural style characterized by pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses, enabling taller and lighter structures.

name: Stained Glass Window Artistry
description: Crafting decorative windows from colored glass, particularly for cathedrals and churches.

name: Universities
description: Institutions of higher learning, growing out of cathedral schools and fostering advanced scholarship.

name: Scholasticism
description: Method of critical thought which dominated teaching in medieval universities, emphasizing dialectical reasoning to resolve contradictions.

name: University Degrees
description: Formal qualifications awarded by universities, signifying mastery in specific fields of study.

name: Gunpowder
description: Explosive mixture of sulfur, charcoal, and potassium nitrate used in early firearms and cannons.

name: Early Medicine
description: Medical practice based on classical texts (humorism), herbal remedies, and limited surgical practices, often practiced in monasteries.

name: Early Hospitals
description: Establishment of institutions dedicated to caring for the sick and infirm, often with religious affiliations.

name: Quarantine & Public Health Measures
description: Isolation practices and early public health interventions to control spread of disease, notably during plagues.

name: Horse Collar
description: Harness allowing horses to pull heavy loads efficiently without choking, revolutionizing agriculture and transport.

name: Horse Shoes
description: Iron shoes nailed to horses' hooves, providing protection and better traction.

name: Heavy Plow (Mouldboard Plow)
description: Advanced plow with a mouldboard to turn over heavy European soils, significantly increasing agricultural productivity.

name: Crop Rotation (Three-Field System)
description: Agricultural practice of rotating crops in three fields to improve soil fertility and yields.

name: Four-Field Crop Rotation
description: Further advancement in crop rotation including fodder crops, enhancing soil fertility and livestock support.

name: Stirrups
description: Device for securing a horseman's feet, enabling more stable riding and the effective use of lances in mounted combat.

name: Advanced Metallurgy (Medieval)
description: Improved techniques for smelting, forging, and heat-treating metals like steel.

name: Watermills
description: Using water power for grinding, sawing, and other industrial processes, becoming a key power source.

name: Blast Furnace
description: Furnace capable of producing large quantities of high-quality iron by using a continuous blast of air, often water-powered.

name: Chainmail Armor Smithing
description: Crafting flexible armor from interlinked metal rings, offering good protection against cutting weapons.

name: Plate Armor
description: Full suits of articulated steel plate offering superior protection, made possible by advanced forging techniques.

name: Heavy Cavalry
description: Mounted knights equipped with plate armor and lances, dominant in medieval warfare.

name: Crossbow
description: Mechanical bow that shoots bolts with great force, requiring less training than a longbow.

name: Trebuchet (Counterweight Siege Engine)
description: Powerful siege engine using a counterweight to hurl large projectiles.

name: Windmills
description: Harnessing wind power for grinding grain and pumping water, especially in areas without strong rivers.

name: Water-Powered Trip Hammers & Forges
description: Application of water power to operate heavy hammers for forging metal and other industrial tasks.

name: Mechanical Clocks
description: Weight-driven or spring-driven timekeeping devices with escapement mechanisms, often for public display in clock towers.

name: Spectacles (Eyeglasses)
description: Lenses mounted in a frame to aid vision, initially for presbyopia, extending the working life of scholars and craftsmen.

name: Astrolabe & Quadrant
description: Navigational and astronomical instruments for measuring altitude of celestial bodies.

name: Compass
description: Magnetic device for determining direction, revolutionizing navigation.

name: Portolan Charts & Maritime Navigation
description: Detailed nautical charts with rhumb lines, used with the compass for improved sea navigation.

name: Lateen Sail & Caravel
description: Advanced ship designs like the caravel, incorporating triangular lateen sails for better maneuverability and sailing against the wind.

name: Paper Making
description: Production of paper from pulp (rags, later wood), a cheaper and more versatile writing material than parchment.

name: Book Binding (Codex Production)
description: Techniques for assembling and binding paper pages into codices (books), replacing scrolls.

name: Fine Arts (Medieval)
description: Development of artistic styles in painting, sculpture, and manuscript illumination characteristic of the medieval period.

name: Illuminated Manuscripts & Scribal Art
description: Elaborately decorated handwritten books, often with gold leaf and intricate illustrations, produced in scriptoriums.

name: Cannons
description: Artillery pieces utilizing gunpowder to fire projectiles, challenging the dominance of fortifications.

name: Guilds
description: Associations of artisans or merchants who oversee the practice of their craft/trade in a particular area, setting standards and prices.

name: Trade Leagues
description: Formal alliances of merchant guilds and market towns (e.g., Hanseatic League) to protect mutual trading interests and dominate trade routes.

name: Guild Halls & Trade Centers
description: Construction of dedicated buildings for guild activities, serving as centers for commerce and craft regulation.

name: Banking (Early Forms)
description: Early financial practices like money lending, letters of credit by merchant families and religious orders.

name: Bills of Exchange & Early Finance
description: Financial instruments allowing for transfer of funds without physical currency, facilitating long-distance trade.

name: Legal Systems (Common/Civil Law)
description: Development of more formal and widespread legal frameworks influencing governance and society, based on precedent or statute.

name: Legal Commentary (Glossators)
description: Scholarly analysis and interpretation of Roman law texts, contributing to the development of European legal thought.

name: Heraldry
description: System of hereditary symbols (coats of arms) to identify individuals and families, particularly in warfare and society.
